project-settings-mac-environment-questio: For macOS, do you need to add directories to the PATH or define other environment variables for Docker/Podman or Kubernetes?
project-settings-mac-environment-answer-: On macOS, applications started from the Launchpad, Dock, Finder, and Spotlight do not inherit the user's environment.  As such, this application may not have the environment necessary to invoke Docker/Podman, kubectl, and Helm.  Use this section to add extra directories to the PATH and define the extra environment variables needed.  Please note that this extra environment configuration is only used when invoking Docker/Podman, kubectl, and Helm.
project-settings-domain-location-title: Target Oracle Fusion Middleware Domain Location
project-settings-domain-location-questio: Where would you like the target Oracle Fusion Middleware domain to live?
project-settings-domain-location-help: Where and when the Oracle Fusion Middleware domain will be created.
project-settings-domain-location-mii-lab: Created in the container from the model in the image
project-settings-domain-location-dii-lab: Created as part of the image
project-settings-domain-location-pv-labe: Externally created in a Kubernetes persistent volume
project-settings-domain-location-mii-mes: The WebLogic Kubernetes Operator creates the domain in the container used to represent the Administration Server.
project-settings-domain-location-dii-mes: The WebLogic Image Tool creates the domain inside the image during the image creation process.
project-settings-domain-location-pv-mess: The target domain must already exist in a Kubernetes Persistent Volume that is accessible to the target Kubernetes cluster. Because no new domain is being created, there is no need to have a model.
project-settings-wdt-target-type-questio: What type of Kubernetes cluster would you like to target?
project-settings-wdt-target-type-help: Select the target type to use for preparing the model for and deploying the domain to the target Kubernetes environment.
project-settings-wdt-target-type-answer-: When deploying a domain to Kubernetes, the WebLogic Kubernetes Toolkit UI application needs to know what type of Kubernetes environment you plan to use.
project-settings-image-builder-type-ques: Which program do you want to use for building the new image and pushing it to an image registry?
project-settings-image-builder-type-help: Choose the program that you want to use to build images and push them to an image registry.
project-settings-image-builder-type-answ: You have chosen to use {{imageBuilderType}} to build your new image and push it to an image registry.
project-settings-java-directory-location: Which Java installation would you like to use?
project-settings-oracle-directory-locati: Which Oracle Fusion Middleware installation would you like to use?
project-settings-java-home-help: The JAVA_HOME directory, which is typically the directory where the JDK is installed.
project-settings-java-directory-location: The Java Home directory will be used when running the WebLogic Deploy Tooling and WebLogic Image Tool.
The Java Home directory will be used when running the WebLogic Image Tool.  This field is only required if creating a new primary image on the Image page.
project-settings-oracle-home-help: The directory containing the Oracle Fusion Middleware installation to use.
project-settings-oracle-directory-locati: The Oracle Home directory will be used when running the WebLogic Deploy Tooling.
project-settings-build-tool-type-questio: What tool do you want to use to work with container images?
project-settings-build-tool-type-help: The software package to use to build, push, and pull images.
project-settings-build-tool-help: The path to the executable to use to build, push, and pull images.
project-settings-build-tool-type-answer-: The selected tool will be used to build the target image, as well as logging in, pushing, and pulling images to and from any image registries.
project-settings-build-tool-type-with-pv: The selected tool will be used to build the target image, as well as logging in, pushing, and pulling images to and from any image registries.  These fields are only required when creating a new primary image on the Image page.
project-settings-credential-store-policy: How should the project's credentials be stored for this project?
Specifies if and how credentials will be stored for the project.
project-settings-credential-store-native: Store in Native OS Credential Store
project-settings-credential-store-policy: The Credential Store Policy controls how credentials are handled when the project is saved and loaded.  The options are to store them in the machine's native credential store, store them in the project file encrypted with a passphrase, or not store them at all.
user-settings-dialog-https-proxy-url-hel: The proxy server URL to use for all outbound HTTPS requests (e.g., http://myproxy:80)
user-settings-dialog-bypass-proxy-hosts-: The list of hostnames or patterns to use to set the NO_PROXY environment variable.  Please see NO_PROXY documentation for legal values.
user-settings-dialog-wrc-home-macos-help: The location of the WebLogic Remote Console.app, typically /Applications/WebLogic Remote Console.app.
user-settings-dialog-wrc-home-windows-he: The location of the WebLogic Remote Console installation directory.
user-settings-dialog-wrc-home-linux-help: The location of the WebLogic Remote Console installation.  For RPM or DEB installers, this will typically be /opt/WebLogic Remote Console.  If using the AppImage, simply point to the AppImage file directly.
user-settings-dialog-wrc-home-tooltip: Choose the WebLogic Remote Console Install Directory
user-settings-dialog-wrc-appimage-toolti: Choose the WebLogic Remote Console AppImage File
user-settings-dialog-console-level-help: The log level to use to filter output to the console.
user-settings-dialog-file-level-help: The log level to use to filter output to the log file.
user-settings-dialog-file-dir-help: The directory to use for writing the application log files.
user-settings-dialog-startup-connectivit: The number of seconds the application will wait for the startup connectivity check response before timing out.
user-settings-dialog-quickstart-section-: WebLogic Kubernetes Toolkit UI Introduction Configuration
user-settings-dialog-quickstart-skip-hel: Whether or not to skip showing the WebLogic Kubernetes Toolkit UI Introduction at application startup.
dialog-passphrase-prompt-label: Please enter the passphrase to use to encrypt the project credential.
model-design-wrc-install-description: The Model Design View is provided through integration with the WebLogic Remote Console.  Install the WebLogic Remote Console on the local machine and use the form below to provide its location and start the daemon process with which the UI will communicate.  Note that this version of the WebLogic Kubernetes Toolkit UI requires version {{wrcVersion}} of the WebLogic Remote Console.
model-design-wrc-install-location-prefix: Download and run the appropriate installer for your machine from the GitHub
model-design-wrc-start-description: After the WebLogic Remote Console is installed, set the WebLogic Remote Console Install Location field below accordingly and click Start WebLogic Remote Console.
model-design-hints-startWebLogicRemoteCo: Start the WebLogic Remote Console backend process
model-code-form-name: Code View tab of the Model

image-code-auxiliary-image-script-no-con: Create New Auxiliary Image is turned off so no content to show.

image-design-image-registry-push-passwor: The image registry password to use to log in to the registry prior to pushing the image.

image-design-custom-base-image-registry-: The base image's registry hostname and port to use to log in to the registry, if required. This field's value is parsed from the Custom Base Image to Use field and an empty value assumes Docker Hub is the registry being used.
image-design-base-image-use-authenticati: Custom Base Image Pull Requires Login
Whether pulling the custom base image requires logging in to the image registry.
image-design-base-image-pull-username-he: The user name to use to pull the custom base image.
image-design-base-image-pull-password-he: The password to use to pull the custom base image.

image-design-aux-default-base-image-use-: By default, the WebLogic Image Tool uses a base image from Docker Hub.  While logging in is not strictly required, Docker Hub is limiting the number of anonymous pull requests so providing your Docker Hub credentials will avoid this limit.
image-design-aux-default-base-image-pull: The user name to use to log into the Docker Hub image registry.
The password to use to log into the Docker Hub image registry.

image-design-aux-image-registry-push-pas: The image registry password to use to log in to the registry prior to pushing the auxiliary image.

image-design-jdk-installer-version-help: The JDK version number to use in the WebLogic Image Tool cache.

image-design-domain-type-help: Specifies the type of Oracle Fusion Middleware domain to be created.
image-design-target-open-shift-help: This option changes the default group name and gives the group file system write access, as required by OpenShift.  Oracle recommends that you only enable this switch if you are deploying to OpenShift.
image-design-files-owner-help: The OS user to create inside the new image.  This user will own all installation files and directories, and run all installers inside the new image.
image-design-files-group-help: The OS group to create inside the new image.  This group will own all installation files and directories, and to run installers inside the new image.
image-design-always-pull-base-image-help: Always attempt to pull a newer version of base images during the build.
image-design-build-network-name-help: The network name to use when building the image.

Choose the Additional Build Commands File

image-design-wdt-domain-home-help: The full path to the domain home directory inside the image.

wko-design-k8s-namespace-help: The Kubernetes namespace into which the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator should be installed.
wko-design-k8s-service-account-help: The name of the Kubernetes service account in the operator's namespace that the operator will use to make requests to the Kubernetes API server.
wko-design-wko-deploy-name-label: Helm Release Name to Use for Operator Installation
wko-design-wko-deploy-name-help: The Helm release name used to install the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator.
wko-design-version-label: WebLogic Kubernetes Operator Version to Install
wko-design-version-help: The version used to install the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator.
wko-design-image-tag-help: The WebLogic Kubernetes Operator image to install.
wko-design-image-pull-policy-help: The policy that controls how often the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator image is pulled to the Kubernetes nodes.
wko-design-image-pull-requires-authentic: Specifies whether or not pulling the specified WebLogic Kubernetes Operator image requires authentication.
wko-design-use-existing-secret-help: Specifies whether to use an existing Kubernetes image pull secret.
wko-design-image-pull-secret-name-help: The name of the Kubernetes image pull secret to use to pull the specified image.
wko-design-image-registry-address-help: The hostname (and port) to use in creating the Kubernetes image pull secret, the value of which is extracted from the image tag.
wko-design-image-registry-username-help: The user name to use in creating the Kubernetes image pull secret.
wko-design-image-registry-email-help: The email address to use in creating the Kubernetes image pull secret.
wko-design-image-registry-password-help: The password to use in creating the Kubernetes image pull secret.
wko-design-k8s-namespace-selection-strat: Specifies how the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator will select the set of namespaces that it will manage.
wko-design-k8s-namespace-selection-list-: Namespace {{namespace}} in field Kubernetes Namespaces to Manage
The set of Kubernetes namespaces that the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator will manage.
wko-design-k8s-namespace-selection-selec: The label selector used to match the list of Kubernetes namespaces that the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator will manage.
wko-design-k8s-namespace-selection-regex: The regular expression used to match the list of Kubernetes namespaces that the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator will manage.
wko-design-k8s-role-binding-help: Specifies whether the roles necessary for the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator to manage domains will be granted using a ClusterRoleBinding rather than using RoleBindings in each managed namespace.
wko-design-external-rest-expose-help: Specifies whether the the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator's REST interface is exposed outside of the Kubernetes cluster on the port specified by the 'External REST HTTPS Port' field value.
wko-design-external-rest-port-help: Specifies the node port that should be allocated for the external WebLogic Kubernetes Operator REST API interface.
wko-design-external-rest-secret-label: External REST API Identity Secret Name
wko-design-external-rest-secret-help: The name of the Secret used to store the certificate and private key to use for the external operator REST HTTPS interface. The Secret has to be created in the same namespace of the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator.
wko-design-3rd-party-elk-enabled-help: Specifies whether or not ELK integration for the domain is enabled.
wko-design-3rd-party-logstash-image-help: Specifies the container image containing the version of Logstash to use.
wko-design-3rd-party-elastic-host-help: Specifies the hostname of where Elasticsearch is running.
wko-design-3rd-party-elastic-port-help: Specifies the port number of where Elasticsearch is running.
wko-design-logging-level-help: Specifies the Java logging level for the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator.
wko-design-logging-file-size-limit-help: Specifies the maximum size in bytes of a single log file in the container's /logs/ directory.
wko-design-logging-file-count-limit-help: Specifies the maximum number of log files to retain in the container's /logs/ directory.
wko-design-helm-timeout-help: The number of minutes that the Helm command will wait for the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator install or update command to complete.
domain-design-uid-help: An identification for the domain which is unique in the Kubernetes cluster.
domain-design-namespace-help: The Kubernetes namespace for the domain.
domain-design-domain-home-help: The path to the domain home in the container.  Leave the value empty to use the default value, which varies by target domain location.
domain-design-domain-home-readonly-help: This field is set by the Domain Home Path field in the Advanced Section of the Image page so go there to change its value.
domain-design-domain-type-help: The domain type to be created using the model.
domain-design-domain-type-readonly-help: This field is set by the Domain Type field in the Advanced Section of the Image page so go there to change its value.
domain-design-wls-credential-help: The name of the Kubernetes secret which holds the credentials for a user with administrative privileges.
domain-design-wls-credential-username-he: The name of the WebLogic user with administrative privileges.
domain-design-wls-credential-password-he: The password of the WebLogic user with administrative privileges.
domain-design-pv-volume-name-help: The name to use for the persistent volume in the domain resource specification.
domain-design-pv-volume-mount-path-help: The path in the container where the persistent volume should be mounted.
domain-design-pv-volume-claim-name-help: The name of the persistent volume claim to associate with the persistent volume.

domain-design-pv-volume-log-home-help: The path to use to write the WebLogic Server log files.
domain-design-wko-installed-version-help: The version of the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator that is installed in the Kubernetes cluster.
domain-design-wko-installed-version-tool: Get the installed version of the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator from the Kubernetes cluster.

quickstart-page1-paragraph-1: Ready to get your WebLogic Server domain running in Kubernetes?
quickstart-page1-paragraph-2: This application will guide you through the process of creating a WebLogic Server domain in Kubernetes.
quickstart-page1-list-item-1: This is a native application with its own native application menus.
quickstart-page1-list-item-2: The application is broken out by sections: Model, Image, and Kubernetes. Use the left side navigation pane to switch between these sections.
quickstart-page1-list-item-3: Most sections provide a Design View and Code View page.  Design View is intended to simplify project configuration while Code View shows you the code.
quickstart-page1-list-item-4: Sections contain actions that perform work using external tools, like the WebLogic Kubernetes Toolkit (WebLogic Kubernetes Operator, WebLogic Deploy Tooling, or WebLogic Image Tool), Verrazzano, and other container-related tools (docker/podman, kubectl, and Helm).
quickstart-page2-list-heading: The WKT UI application relies on Internet access for:
quickstart-page2-list-item-1: Downloading style sheets and fonts from the nearest Oracle CDN location.
quickstart-page2-list-item-2: Initializing certain section configuration fields' default values.
quickstart-page2-list-item-3: Checking GitHub for application updates and WKT tool installers.
quickstart-page2-list-item-4: Accessing Docker Hub, GitHub Container Registry, and any other remote Image registries the project specifies.
quickstart-page2-list-item-5: Accessing any remote Kubernetes cluster the project configuration specifies.
quickstart-page2-paragraph-1: As such, it is critical that you review the application preferences to make sure that the Proxy Configuration is correct for your environment.
quickstart-page2-paragraph-2: To access the application preferences, use the Preferences menu item, which is located in the File menu on Windows and Linux and in the application menu on macOS.
quickstart-page2-paragraph-3: Should you have to change the Proxy Configuration, restart the application to make sure the application provides you all the help possible for the default values.
quickstart-page3-paragraph-1: The WKT UI application uses a project file to store user input.
quickstart-page3-list1-heading: Projects are created in two ways:
quickstart-page3-list1-item-1: Explicitly - By using the File menu's New Project menu item.
quickstart-page3-list1-item-2: Implicitly - By working in the application and performing an action that requires saving the project.
quickstart-page3-list2-heading: Important things to understand about the WKT UI project file:
quickstart-page3-list2-item-1: The file is in JSON format and must have a .wktproj file extension.
quickstart-page3-list2-item-2: Only fields with non-default values are saved in the file.
quickstart-page3-list2-item-3: The file only stores references to the WDT model-related files.  While the files are generally treated as part of the project, they are always stored in their WDT files.
quickstart-page3-list2-item-4: Credential fields are never stored in clear text.  They may be stored in the native OS credential store, encrypted in the project file, or not stored at all.
quickstart-page3-paragraph-2: The WKT UI application uses a one project per window paradigm.  If you try to open the same project file more than once, the application will simply bring the existing window into focus to prevent corruption of the file.
quickstart-page4-list1-heading: The Project Settings section defines key configuration values used throughout the application.  These include:
quickstart-page4-list1-item-2: Where to create the WebLogic Server domain relative to the image.
quickstart-page4-list1-item-3: What is the WebLogic Deploy Tooling target type that most closely matches your Kubernetes cluster.
quickstart-page4-list1-item-4: Which Java Home and Oracle Home directories to use for running the WKT tools.
quickstart-page4-list1-item-5: Which image build tool to use--Docker or podman.
quickstart-page4-list2-heading: Where you store the credentials affects sharing of the project file; the options are:
quickstart-page4-list2-item-1: Storing the credentials in the native OS credential store means that the credentials are only stored on the local machine.
quickstart-page4-list2-item-2: Storing the passphrase-encrypted credentials in the WKT project file means that you have to know the passphrase needed to decrypt the credentials.
quickstart-page4-list2-item-3: Not storing the credentials means that you need to re-enter credentials whenever the project file is opened.
quickstart-page4-list3-heading: Where you store the domain affects the life cycle of the domain; the options are:
quickstart-page4-list3-item-1: Storing the model of the domain in the image. WebLogic Kubernetes Operator creates the domain inside the containers started from the image.
quickstart-page4-list3-item-2: Storing the domain in the image. WebLogic Image Tool creates the domain while it is creating the image.
quickstart-page4-list3-item-3: Storing the domain in a Kubernetes persistent volume. The persistent volume and domain are created outside of this application and WebLogic Kubernetes Operator attaches the persistent volume to the domain's containers.
quickstart-page5-paragraph-1: WebLogic Deploy Tooling (WDT) defines a metadata model for describing a WebLogic Server domain.
quickstart-page5-list1-heading: This metadata model consists of three components:
quickstart-page5-list1-item-2: Variables - Defines a set of tokens to be used in the model and their values.
quickstart-page5-list1-item-3: Archive - Contains application-related and domain-related files and directories to be added to the domain.
quickstart-page5-list2-heading: The WKT UI application supports creating, discovering, importing, and editing WDT metadata models.
quickstart-page5-list2-item-1: Use the File menu's Add Model menu to discover a model from a domain or import existing model files.
quickstart-page5-list2-item-2: Use the Model section to create new or edit existing model-related files.
quickstart-page6-list-heading: The Model Design View page allows the WebLogic Remote Console {{wrcVersion}} to provide a familiar graphical interface for viewing and editing the model-related files.
quickstart-page6-list-item-1: On the left side is the Navigation bar that supports navigating into different areas of the model.
quickstart-page6-list-item-2: The right side shows the model content for the selected part of the model to add, remove, or edit model objects and values.
quickstart-page6-list-item-3: Above the right side model content, the Search Model control provides access to the WebLogic Remote Console search functionality for locating objects in the model.
quickstart-page6-paragraph-1: In the action button bar, the Prepare Model button (or the Go menu item) optimizes the model for Kubernetes deployment.
quickstart-page6-paragraph-2: When running certain actions, such as Prepare Model, the collapsed Console panel automatically appears and displays the stdout and stderr streams.
quickstart-page7-list-heading: The Model Code View page provides three panes that support viewing and editing the model-related files.
quickstart-page7-list-item-1: On the left side is the Model Editor that supports editing the model.
quickstart-page7-list-item-2: In the upper right is the Variable Editor that supports adding, removing, and updating variable names and their values.
quickstart-page7-list-item-3: In the lower right is the Archive Editor that supports adding, removing, and updating files and directories in the archive.
quickstart-page7-paragraph-1: In the action button bar, the Validate Model button (or the Go menu item) supports validating the model to ensure that it is syntactically correct.  This is particularly valuable when editing the model in the Model Code View.
quickstart-page8-paragraph-1: The WKT UI application supports creating a suitable Linux image for deploying your WebLogic Server-based domain.
quickstart-page8-list1-heading: When creating an image, you need to specify which:
quickstart-page8-list1-item-1: Image Tag to apply to the new image.
quickstart-page8-list1-item-2: Image Registry Push credentials to use to push the image to the registry specified in the Image Tag.
quickstart-page8-paragraph-2: The collapsible Advanced section provides access to other configuration that might be required in your environment.
quickstart-page8-list2-heading: Patching the Oracle Fusion Middleware installation is optional but strongly recommended. The application allows you to get:
quickstart-page8-list2-item-1: All Recommended Patches (which includes the latest PSU).
quickstart-page8-paragraph-3: All patches will be downloaded automatically using your Oracle Support user name and password.
quickstart-page9-paragraph-1: The WKT UI application requires the Kubernetes client tool kubectl to be properly configured to connect to your Kubernetes cluster.
quickstart-page9-list-heading: This section of the application helps you configure kubectl to be able to connect to your cluster:
quickstart-page9-list-item-1: Select the Kubernetes cluster provider type to see instructions for configuring kubectl for your cluster.
quickstart-page9-list-item-2: After configuring kubectl using the provided instructions, specify the correct values for the configuration properties in the section.
quickstart-page9-list-item-3: Use the Verify Connectivity action to make sure the application is able to connect to the cluster.
quickstart-page10-paragraph-1: When using the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator as the WDT target type, the following sections will be shown.
quickstart-page10-list2-heading: This section makes it easy to install the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator into your Kubernetes cluster.
quickstart-page10-list2-item-1: Design view provides values for the various Kubernetes objects and Helm chart value overrides.
quickstart-page10-list2-item-2: Code view provides a shell script that shows how you can automate the installation.
quickstart-page10-list2-item-3: The Install Operator button (and Go menu item) performs the necessary actions to install the operator.
quickstart-page10-list3-heading: This section makes it easy to deploy the Kubernetes objects needed by the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator to deploy the domain and start the servers.
quickstart-page10-list3-item-1: Design view provides values for the various Kubernetes objects, including model variable override values and secret values.
quickstart-page10-list3-item-2: Code view provides a shell script that shows how you can automate the installation as well as the YAML resource definitions.
quickstart-page10-list3-item-3: The Deploy Domain button (and Go menu item) performs the necessary actions to deploy the Kubernetes objects required by the operator.
quickstart-page10-list3-item-4: The Get Domain Status button (and Go menu item) queries the Kubernetes cluster to determine the status of the last domain deployment action.
quickstart-page10-list4-heading: This section makes it easy to expose your domain's endpoint outside the cluster, as well as to install an ingress controller.
quickstart-page10-list4-item-1: Design view provides values for the various Kubernetes objects and Helm chart value overrides.
quickstart-page10-list4-item-2: Code view provides a shell script that shows how you can automate the installation as well as the YAML resource definitions.
quickstart-page10-list4-item-3: The Install Ingress Controller and Update Ingress Routing buttons (and Go menu items) perform the necessary actions to install the ingress controller and update routes on an existing ingress controller.
quickstart-page11-paragraph-1: When using Verrazzano as the WDT target type, the following sections will be shown.
quickstart-page11-list2-heading: This section makes it easy to install Verrazzano into your Kubernetes cluster.
quickstart-page11-list2-item-1: Design view provides values for the various fields needed to install Verrazzano, including installation of the optional Jaeger component.
quickstart-page11-list2-item-2: Code view provides a shell script that shows how you can automate the installation.
quickstart-page11-list2-item-3: The Install Verrazzano button (and Go menu item) performs the necessary actions to install Verrazzano.
quickstart-page11-list3-heading: This section provides support for creating and deploying the Verrazzano component for the WebLogic domain.
quickstart-page11-list3-item-1: Design view provides values for the various Kubernetes objects, including model variable override values and secret values.
quickstart-page11-list3-item-2: Code view provides a shell script for deploying the Verrazzano component for this WebLogic domain into Verrazzano and creating its dependent resources, as well as the YAML resource definitions.
quickstart-page11-list3-item-3: The Deploy Component button (and Go menu item) creates the domain custom object and any of its dependent objects (for example, namespace, secrets, ConfigMap) in Kubernetes.
quickstart-page11-list4-heading: This section makes it easy to compose an application that includes the component for the WebLogic domain.
quickstart-page11-list4-item-1: Design view provides values for defining the application and customizing it for the target environment.
quickstart-page11-list4-item-2: Code view provides a shell script for deploying the Verrazzano application for the WebLogic domain into Verrazzano as well as the application YAML resource definition and, if applicable, the project resource definition.
quickstart-page11-list4-item-3: The Deploy Application button (and Go menu item) deploys the application to Verrazzano.
